title: Monday, 8th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

Hello. Hi. Good morning.

BE

So congratulations to the Minnesota Astroturfs or whatever for winning the Superbowl.

BE

Congratulations, also, to Paul Murphy for being in Mozambique.

11:04 am
BE

Again.

BE

Which means we're contractually obliged to link to this.

BE

Again.

11:04 am
BE

http://www.theguar...urdaytravelsection

BE

Oh, sorry.

BE

That was the one he wrote for the Guardian, in 2004.

11:04 am
BE

Here's the updated travelogue: http://www.ft.com/...d20eaf.html#slide0

BE

(Again.)

BE

But it's early February and I for one don't want to look at a picture of a beach.

11:05 am
BE

So instead, portrait of the day is Mr Steven Hopwood

BE

Or Hoppy.

BE

11:06 am
BE

Hoppy was a very popular sales trader throughout the mid-2000s.

BE

Jefferies, Panmure, Lazard and WestLB, among others.

BE

He then jacked it in in 2008 to become, somewhat unusually, a professional cage fighter.

11:06 am
BE

And now he's in Monaco, apparently. I only note all this because his profile's the most viewed on the Bloomberg terminal this morning.

BE

And I'm not sure why. If anyone is, the best way to contact me is firstname.lastname@ft.com

undefined
11:08 am
BE

To the market, though. And it's a bleak one.

BE

Even in the context of the recent volatility spike. FTSE down 1.8% at pixel.

BE

108 points at 5739

11:09 am
BE

Lots of talk on the wires about growth concerns

BE

Along with the Great NIM crush, perhaps best represented by Deutsche Bank CoCos.

BE

11:10 am
BE

But I think Joseph has a post coming soon on that, so I won't pre-empt it.

BE

Instead, let's head to the blow-up of the day.

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 121.75, down 10 (-7.59%), High: 132.50, Low: 108.00, Volume: 2.30m
11:13 am
BE

(Thanks for all the emails on Hoppy, by the way. Sorry to say that it seems our worst fears are confirmed. Sad news.)

BE

...... Profit warning, with everything going wrong but no specific reasons given.

BE

Pure to be disposed, at long last.

11:14 am
BE

CEO out.

BE

Shares seem to be rallying on the idea that it's going to put IMG in play.

BE

As in, the core graphics IP business remains valuable (assuming Apple doesn't go elsewhere)

11:16 am
BE

Personally, I'd want a clearer view on what's gone wrong here. Visibility is rather poor.

BE

I'd also want a clearer idea about what kind of costs are going to go with Pure. The capex overlap has never been entirely clear to me.

BE

But that's getting ahead of myself. Here's JP Morgan.

11:17 am
BE

Imagination Tech has announced a CEO change, indicated weaker trading in
2H of fiscal year and announced restructuring measures including putting Pure
up for sale while refocusing the spending in the existing business. We foresaw
a difficult 2HFY16 in our note Imagination Technologies: Multiple 2HFY16
royalty headwinds point to lack of stock performance. Downgrade to Neutral,
dated 27 Nov 2015. The measures announced are substantial with the opex cut
9% of our FY16 estimates, but it is likely even higher excluding Pure, which
is considered as discontinued. Imagination has major new contracts that start
ramping up in FY17 and, with the cost measures put in place, the company
could see a profit rebound. However, given the difficult near-term conditions
and the considerable change being implemented there may be reason for some
short-term caution.

BE

 CEO change: Imagination has announced that Sir Hossein Yassaie has
stepped down as the CEO with immediate effect. Andrew Heath, one of the
non-executive directors, has been appointed interim CEO. Mr. Heath has
held executive roles at Rolls-Royce and was more recently the CEO of Alent
plc. The company is starting the search for a new CEO immediately.

BE

 Weaker trading to result in an EBIT loss for FY16 (ending Apr ’16):
Imagination has indicated that since its half-year results in Dec ’15, royalty
returns from some key customers have fallen short of previous expectations
for C4Q15 with lower forecasts for C1Q16. Further, while the licence
pipeline remains strong, the pace of deal closure is falling short of prior
expectations with licence revenue already secured of £24m (our estimate for
FY16 licensing revenue is £40.2m vs. £39m in FY15). As a result, the
company’s expectations for FY16 group revenue has reduced materially and
it expects to report underlying EBIT loss for FY16. Company-compiled
consensus FY16 underlying EBIT is a profit of £4.6m.

11:18 am
BE

 Restructuring initiatives announced including the sale of Pure: The
company plans to sell Pure. In addition, it expects to cut total operating costs
in the ongoing business (excluding Pure) in FY17 by £15m gross, of which
£2m will be reinvested in the core Power VR IP business, resulting in a new
£13m cut to costs. Imagination will also initiate a full operational review,
expected to last several months, to ensure investment is focused on core
activities, which look set to deliver attractive returns.

BE

Investec are more positive, at least for the long term.

BE

magination’s statement makes for grim superficial reading, but in our view represents a technology “special sit” finally starting to take the necessary action to sort itself out. We expect the core GPU, MIPS and Ensigma businesses to be retained, with a more surgical investment approach, but for IMG Works and Systems to be the focus of the cost reduction plan. The debt situation is not great but an equity raise still looks unlikely. A reversal of margin destruction could in time re-rate the shares, and we stay at Buy.

11:19 am
BE

Imagination’s third profit warning of the year is not specific beyond referring both to royalties and licences, and suggesting the group will record a loss for FY16 versus the consensus expectation of c.£4m EBIT.
The cost reduction plan outlined is broadly as we expected in terms of quantum, at £15m for FY17. We expect this to be focused on IMG Works and IMG Systems. The sale of Pure brings a further £5m benefit, which is immediate in terms of now being recorded as a discontinued business. A more surgical approach to the retained GPU MIPS Ensigma businesses means total cost savings for FY17E could be £25m. As a result, the outlook for how FY17E EBIT will change is hard to estimate ahead of the analyst call.
The interim net debt looked ugly but with over £50m of property assets, recently extended banking facilities and a large royalty cheque from its largest customer due in calendar Q1 related to the Dec quarter, we do not think there is any serious risk of an equity raise in the short term.
In our view this warning, and the departure of the founding CEO, will initially be taken as a negative by the market, but in reality represents an IP-loaded “special sit” finally taking action to sort itself out. The core GPU business (c.£100m revenue at a c.40% EBIT margin) is strategically valuable and, while we believe it is highly dependent on Apple, has prospects for FY17 growth through Mediatek and Spreadtrum. The jury is out on both MIPS and Ensigma, but a trend EV/Sales of 5x suggests a reversal of the margin destruction of recent years could re-rate the shares. We retain our Buy and TP. Our forecasts are under review.

BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

Value: With the exit of the CEO today, we believe all options are on the table,
including further significant restructuring and partial or full divestment. The key
elements of value within IMG are 1) its IP portfolio, 2) its highly profitable
graphics revenue stream and 3) MIPS royalties. The company would argue that
the IP portfolio is worth up to $1bn (and we have previously said at least £250m
although this is relatively speculative). Graphics generates c£100m a year total
revenue and we believe is generating mature margins. MIPS is generating

£20m

a year in royalties. It is therefore possible that an exercise could be run to extract
maximum short-term value from the Group. The core tension has been the level
of investment required to secure the long-term growth outlook by combining a
broader range of IP and making a play in the CPU and RF markets. Arguably the
risk-reward for that investment does not currently look that attractive.

11:20 am
BE

Overall, despite the downgrades, today’s announcements are positive for the
shares in that they will start to catalyse the realisation of value within this Group
by a more dispassionate management team.

BE

@J in Tokyo raises the interesting idea of Apple buying Imagination, which is a perennial sort of rumour.

BE

One would have to ask what Apple would get out of it that it couldn't get by just buying a licence.

11:22 am
BE

It's not like it's going to mess with Mediatek or whoever if they had to switch to Mali.

undefined
BE

In terms of Arm ............

11:23 am
ARM Holdings PLC (ARM:LSE): Last: 936.00, down 47 (-4.78%), High: 982.00, Low: 925.50, Volume: 2.38m
BE

Yeah, there's the Imagination readthrough, though there's not much of that.

BE

More pressingly, perhaps, it seems the consensus is drifting a bit lower ahead of Wednesday's earnings.

11:24 am
BE

Here's BMO, for instance.

BE

For ARM, we are adjusting our 2016 estimates due to lower USD/GBP exchange rate partly offset by lower USD revenues. Our USD revenue estimates are based on lower smartphone unit shipments than we were previously modeling. Our 2016E EPS goes to 35.7 pence vs. our prior estimate of 33.5 pence. We are also introducing our 2017 estimates including USD revenues of $1.87 billion, up 11% y-y, reported revenues of £1.30 billion, up 13% y-y, and EPS of 40.2 pence. Our 2017 estimates are based on a USD/GBP rate of 1.44.
For 4Q15 and 1Q16, we are largely in line with consensus. For 4Q15, we expect USD revenues of $399 million, up 6% q-q. We expect reported revenues of £259 million, up 6% q-q, and EPS of 7.9 pence, vs. consensus’ estimate for revenue of £263 million, up 8%, and EPS of 8.2 pence. For 1Q16, we expect reported revenues of £262 million, flat q-q, and EPS of 7.8 pence, compared with consensus’ estimates for revenue of £263 million, flat q-q and EPS of 8.1 pence. Our 1Q16 estimates are based on a USD/GBP FX rate of 1.52, vs. our 4Q15 rate assumption of 1.54.

BE

And Credit Suisse.

11:25 am
BE

For ARM, we expect Q4 group revenues of
$399mn (+6% qoq/+12% yoy) or £262mn, driving EPS of 8.22p. Within this, we
assume Licensing sales of $139mn (+10% qoq/+0% yoy; in-line with consensus).
For Royalties, we model $192mn (+4% qoq/+28% yoy; vs. consensus at
$195mn). While we acknowledge concerns around slowing smartphone unit
growth, given royalty rates remain on the rise and long term opportunity around
Networking, IoT and Auto, we believe ARM can deliver ~10%/15% sales/EPS
CAGR over 2015-2018, and hence we maintain OP.

BE

Smartphone + Tablet unit growth slowing; Royalty rate to provide offset....
Given ARM reports royalties by a quarter lag, we note that global smartphone +
tablet unit shipments grew 5%/3% yoy in Q315/Q415 (clear slowdown from
12%/10% growth in Q1/Q215). However, with ARM outgrowing the smartphone
market and overall semi market materially driven principally by content increase,
we expect this trend to continue. As such, we model Royalty growth of 28%/20%
yoy for Q415/Q116 (corresponding quarters). Beyond that, we see some level of
deceleration with royalties growing at 14% yoy over the remainder of 2016.

BE

…but will it be enough? Consensus seems high on Royalties; FX a tailwind
on EPS. For 2016, we model US$ Royalties to grow 15% yoy, below consensus
at 20%. Specifically for Smartphones (~55% of Royalties), we model 17% growth
in Royalties which assumes 5% smartphone unit growth, 5% decline in chip
ASPs and royalty rate rising from 1.75% to 2.05% due to increasing penetration
of 64-bit and multi-core processors. Given we expect limited benefit from royalty
growth in newer verticals like Networking or Auto in the near term (as it may take
longer to benefit), we believe consensus at 20% Royalty growth may prove a bit
high. But on the other hand, GBP/USD has moved from 1.52 for Q415 to 1.45
currently, so a 4.5% move in FX can theoretically imply around 7% potential
upside to our EPS estimates, which are 5-7% below consensus.

11:26 am
undefined
BE

ROTR, it's going to be slow today. There's not much news, very little volume, and the Sunday papers were woeful.

BE

If there's a day to heckle randomly, today is it.

11:28 am
BE

Thankfully, though, we have Just sell

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 352.00, down 27.4 (-7.22%), High: 381.20, Low: 345.20, Volume: 1.36m
BE

Which is correcting Friday's inexplicable pop

11:29 am
BE

And we can perhaps blame a New York Post story over the weekend about Uber and Amazon

BE

http://nypost.com/...out-food-delivery/

BE

Uber and Amazon are launching slick new apps that promise to widen the market for high-tech food delivery — but the bill for restaurants won’t be cheap.
Uber will begin in March to deploy its vast network of taxis and bike couriers to deliver gourmet pizzas, burgers and salads through its new “UberEats” platform — and will demand an unprecedentedly steep 30 percent cut of the bill from restaurants, sources told The Post.
Amazon won’t be far behind, with plans to charge eateries 27.5 percent of the check, according to interviews with persons briefed on the situation and documents reviewed by The Post.

11:30 am
BE

And needless to say, there's sellside.

BE

Such as Jefferies.

BE

JUST EAT (JE/ LN): Clarifying the UK Competitive Dynamics Debate

11:30 am
BE

"Clarifying"

BE

As in, "you don't understand. Let us explain."

BE

The FY15 trading update. 12th January, FY15 LfL order growth +46%, suggests a 4Q15 +43% number after a surprisingly high 3Q15 +48% number, 1Q15, 2Q15 +47%. Does this suggest UK competition taking its toll? Not in our view.
Debating UK competition. Connected to perhaps a misread of the trading update and seeking to explain a slowing UK order growth dynamic by characterising the market as becoming 'crowded' and 'increasingly competitive', the impact and relevance of Deliveroo-style 'last mile' models has been over-stated.

11:30 am
BE

"a misread"

BE

So here we go yet again. Market fragmentation as a positive.

BE

Deliveroo hits different restaurants, higher end, often casual dining restaurants seeking to generate incremental orders in the quieter parts of the dining week. The last thing these restaurants want to do is cannibalise seated dining, it will only ever be of limited import to their business model. It hits different consumers too, those spending more money and happy to pay up for delivery.

11:31 am
BE

All of which is true-ish. Except it isn't.

BE

People don't eat out as an alternative to eating in. That rather misunderstands why people go out.

BE

We're also heading back into the surreal world where independent operators are meant to be cheaper than chain operators.

11:32 am
BE

Which takes literally seconds to disprove.

BE

As in, pizza menu from Ask on Shad Thames, via Deliveroo

BE

11:32 am
BE

And pizza menu from Oregano Leaf on Camberwell Church Street, via Just Eat.

BE

BE

Literally the first ones I landed on.

11:32 am
BE

Back to Jefferies, though.

BE

It's a different market to JE, both for restaurants and consumers. JE hits the mass market, JE's restaurants want to retain the delivery piece and their analytical understanding of 'last mile' models comes from years of experience of executing it in Denmark and Brazil. The current 'London Loves' offer is another example.
JE's analysis shows that in postcodes where Deliveroo and JE both operate, there has been no measurable impact on KPI's around customer acquisition, order frequency, restaurant capture etc. We believe JE's reluctance to engage in scale 'last mile' a la GRUB is the right strategic call for the business, the right call in terms of the financial shape of the income statement and indeed the right call in terms delivering on the equity thesis.

BE

Yes, Deliveroo is aiming for a market slightly different from Just Eat.

11:33 am
BE

(And is doing it with money provided by the same folk who backed pre-float Just Eat.)

BE

But what of Amazon and Uber?

BE

Welcome to Monday. Gong Xi Fa Cai, as every single broker summary began this morning.

11:33 am
BE

.... and the other is a company that has corralled a 1m strong army that pays to do its bidding.

BE

Deliveroo's the stalking horse in this market.

BE

The stalking ........... kangaroo.

11:34 am
BE

Whatever.

BE

There is a but.... There always is and for JE it is that the strategic decision not to engage in 'last mile' emphasises the imperative to deliver value to the restaurants, to construct a competitive moat around the restaurant network and to innovate in the provision of multiple value propositions to their restaurant partners.
The recent M&A...To some extent expected, online classified players such as Schibsted and Naspers have consolidated geographies via M&A very successfully and the resulting economics of 'real market leadership' are very compelling.
What is surprising perhaps is the speed with which JE have out-competed RKET in Italy and Spain...though we have made the point before that JE execute very well, worth remembering that CEO Buttress was employee number one in the UK. Clearly M&A never cheap in this sector, but Friday's news flow is very positive for JE's international aspirations.

BE

"to construct a competitive moat around the restaurant network and to innovate in the provision of multiple value propositions to their restaurant partners"

11:34 am
BE

Jees.

undefined
BE

So ..............

11:36 am
BE

Tech's not really grabbing the ROTR. Oil services, maybe?

BE

It's IP Week.

BE

Though the parties are more restrained than usual, we're told.

11:37 am
BE

Trafigura isn't even hosting one.

BE

Glencore's booked a function room at the Dorchester.

BE

David, Neil etc have all the detail here: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3zZHoM25P

11:38 am
BE

Meanwhile, good note out from the ever excellent Christyan Malek of Nomura

BE

Who argues that the depth of slough oil services find themselves in should merit at a 45% discount to the wider market

BE

We think the OFS downturn will be protracted as the industry remains in oversupply and exacerbated by a structural decline in deepwater capex (we forecast a 30% fall y-o-y in 2016 spend) as highlighted in our Global Capex Outlook. [...] in 1999, the group traded at a 42% discount to the market. We think the sector’s structural characteristics are closest to that period in history as global industry capex remained at depressed levels for several years and returns were capped by weak pricing and excess capacity.

11:39 am
BE

As in ......

BE

BE

So ........

11:39 am
BE

Our strategy team projects a forward P/E of 13x in 2017 for the European equity market, consistent with intensified European Central Bank (ECB) money creation, gradually strengthening credit transmission, and Nomura rates strategy expectations for a c40bp backing up of 10-year Bund yields (from the current c35bp to an end-year level of 75bp). After European stocks’ considerable -9% (net) pullback since the start of the year, the team now sees the balance of risks for European equities as skewed more to the upside, enabling local-currency outperformance vs most global peers over FY16 as orderly EUR/USD depreciation and a (very) modest, gradual reflationary cyclical recovery drive above-consensus EPS growth of c7-8%.

BE

Our company target prices are derived from our sector 2017E P/E and EV/DACF multiples and benchmarked against the European equity market. Applying a 45% discount to the European market multiple of 13x suggests a P/E of 7.2x in 2017 for the OFS group. Given EV/DACF multiples are not available for the European market, we use the historical relationship between the sector EV/DACF to P/E to derive the equivalent 2017E EV/DACF for the OFS group. We calculate that the sector P/E delta to EV/DACF is c36%, on average, since 2000 (we do not have meaningful data to calculate sector EV/DACF before 2000) and from 2010, it has oscillated around c30%. Using this more recent premium and assuming it is broadly unchanged across our forecast horizon, implies a EV/DACF of 5.0x in 2017 for the OFS group.

BE

Therefore, buy companies with Middle East contracts and sell everything else.

11:40 am
BE

In traffic-light form, here's what that looks like .....

BE

BE

Or on a corporate view ...........

11:40 am
BE

Technip (Reduce, EUR 25 TP): we forecast backlog to fall by 26% in 2016, led by a fall in deepwater capex. This should drive a 590bp contraction in subsea EBIT margin in 2015-17 and leaves us 10%/33% below consensus 2016E/17E EPS.

BE

Subsea 7 (Reduce, NOK 45 TP): we remain negative on the name owing to worse-than-expected operational gearing and cancellation of PLSV Brazil contracts, leaving us 24/33% below consensus 2016E/17E EPS.

BE

Wood Group (Reduce, 350p TP): we believe valuation is demanding and model 11%/15% risk to 2016/17 consensus EPS led by margin decline in engineering and production-sharing network (PSN).

11:41 am
BE

AMEC (Neutral, 360p TP): we cut our 2016E/17E EBITA by 21%/31% and argue that the risk/reward on the balance sheet is negative. Moreover, we highlight risk of kitchen-sinking under the leadership of a new CEO.

BE

Petrofac (Buy, 850p TP): offers good value in the context of structural growth in Middle East spend and an improved returns outlook as capital intensity falls (2017E P/E: 7.4x; vs sector: 13.0x).

John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 586.00, down 44.5 (-7.06%), High: 618.00, Low: 585.50, Volume: 814.16k
11:42 am
Amec Foster Wheeler PLC (AMFW:LSE): Last: 392.60, down 23.9 (-5.74%), High: 410.10, Low: 389.20, Volume: 910.45k
BE

There's also a Goldman upgrade around on the sector, though that came out on Friday so probably won't help much this morning.

BE

Here's the upshot of it.

11:44 am
BE

We expect cash outflows on working capital, risks to profit
In this report, we focus on working capital analysis, which we believe will
be the key theme for the oil services sector in 2016. As low oil prices lead
to negative free cash flow generation for oil producers, we believe oil
services companies will face delayed payments that they will largely have
to accept given the high competition for new orders created by a lack of
order intake in the industry. We expect a negative funding gap, mostly
driven by a build-up of receivables. We highlight Tenaris and Hunting as
having opportunities to destock, while we see working capital risks for
Petrofac, Wood Group, Aker Solutions, Fugro, PGS and CGG.

BE

Valuation: Sector at trough EV/GCI; coverage view up to Neutral
We have long argued that in order to turn less bearish on the sector, we
would need to see it trading at trough EV/GCI – a point at which valuation
would reflect the fundamental shifts and structural deflation in the industry.
Following the ytd sell-off, we believe the sector is now trading at trough
EV/GCI, and thus raise our coverage view to Neutral from Cautious. We
move from an EV/EBITDA-based valuation to an EV/GCI framework and
update our estimates to reflect recent market trends.

BE

Buy structural winners, sell deepwater/cash-squeezed companies
We view the sector’s current trough EV/GCI valuation as offering an
attractive entry point into industry leaders with strong balance sheets,
namely Technip and Tenaris, which we upgrade to Buy from Neutral. We
would avoid E&Cs that appear at risk of a build-up in receivables and therefore
an expanding funding gap, putting pressure on cash flow generation. We
downgrade Petrofac to Neutral from Buy on receivables build-up risks and a
more moderate outlook for order intake in the Middle East. We downgrade
Aker Solutions to Sell from Neutral as we expect increasing competition in
the subsea market in the absence of orders from integrated oils, and think
the risk of receivables build-up is also high. For the same reasons, we remain
Sell rated on Subsea 7. We also downgrade Wood Group to Sell (from
Neutral) and add it to our Conviction List, as we see risks of a material miss
vs. 2016 consensus expectations given indications of spending cuts from US
E&Ps and muted North Sea activity. In our view, the market overestimates the
company’s resilience in the current environment. We reiterate our CL-Buy on
Hunting based on the strong recovery we expect in 2017 in the US, to which
the company is geared. Hunting also screens as a potential M&A candidate.

11:45 am
BE

Wood also mentioned as an M&A candidate further down the note. But we've done that story already, and have nothing to add.

BE

(@cheeckychappy: yes, true. And to be fair, I thought that PE failed bid archeology thing in the Sunday Times was quite entertaining.)

undefined
11:46 am
BE

Regarding Inmarsat, as mentioned on the right ........

BE

(@cheeckychappy: a good read, that's all. I wasn't being snarky.)

BE

.... Barclays downgrade.

11:47 am
BE

"Year of transition" stuff.

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 987.00, down 33 (-3.24%), High: 1,025, Low: 972.50, Volume: 771.12k
BE

And not cheap enough

11:48 am
BE

ISAT is a global play on rising demand for connectivity anywhere/anytime. Over the
past ten years it has posted strong growth and we see more ahead as it has invested
in many new projects. We forecast a 5Y revenue CAGR of +8% and EPS of +16% over
the same period. However, we also see three negatives: 1) Market expectations
seem too optimistic: we are below consensus EBITDA for 16e/17e; 2) Execution risk
is higher than before as growth is driven by new technologies and products; 3)
Competition is rising with the emergence of HTS. We believe these risks are not
reflected in valuation: ISAT is at a premium to fundamentals and historical
multiples, leaving little room for error. Following the strong stock price
performance over the last 3Y, we downgrade to UW with an increased PT of GBP10.
This implies a c. 2% downside potential vs c. +20% upside on average for European
telecom stocks and c. +5% for satellites.

BE

Growth to accelerate, but execution and competition risk is higher than before. With
the GX fleet now fully operative and the upcoming ATG-S infrastructure, we forecast a
5Y revenue CAGR of +8% with rising margins (+6pp) leading to strong EPS growth
(+16% 5Y CAGR). This is above the company’s historical growth (10Y CAGR of +6% for
core revenues and + 15% for EPS). However, GX is a brand new fleet that will require
customers to replace their existing antennas; ATG-S is only being built and could face
deployment and acceptance issues. Also the competitive environment is getting
tougher: HTS is bringing new players into satellites and blurring the lines between FSS
and MSS, with large players in the former specifically targeting some of ISAT’s markets.

BE

Priced for perfection. ISAT has outperformed significantly in the past 3Y and now
trades at an 8Y peak on forward P/E (c.30x). Our DCF (8.5% WACC, 2.5% terminal
growth) points to a value of GBP10. The upside/downside range is material, reflecting
our wide range of potential growth outcomes. We have extensively remodeled the
business for 2015 developments and are now c. -5% to -8% below 16e/17e Bloomberg
consensus EBITDA. ISAT should provide a 3Y guidance at its Q4 results in March.

11:49 am
undefined
BE

Cripes, it's slow. I would do some extremely flaky RAW, I guess, but don't want to be held responsible for any kind of silliness in a thin market.

BE

...... Instead, I guess we could give some traffic to the Sunday Times Glencore story.

11:53 am
BE

(@squarepeg: apologies, we have to be responsible. It's not that you lot on the ROTR can't be trusted, but the lurkers here can be proper muppets.)

BE

Here's the upshot of the Sunday Times.

BE

GLENCORE is set to unveil a deal to bring in at least $500m as part of its frantic efforts to slash its debt.

The commodities giant is in advanced talks on a "streaming" deal, under which it would hand future precious metal production from a mine in Chile to American gold specialist Franco-Nevada, in exchange for an upfront payment. The agreement could be unveiled as soon as this week.

It is part of a $13bn (£9bn) fundraising campaign that Glencore launched last year to scotch concerns over its $30bn net debt.

Glencore shares plunged 70% last year, making it the worst-performing stock in the FTSE 100 after rival Anglo American. Miners and oil companies have been hit hard by the collapse in raw material prices after a decade-long commodities boom came to a halt. Much of the malaise has been caused by a slump in demand in China just as huge new projects came into production. The prices of oil, copper, iron ore and coal have all plunged, forcing companies into drastic action.

11:53 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 100.00, down 2.15 (-2.10%), High: 106.60, Low: 98.82, Volume: 35.71m
BE

Now, $500m is considerably less than its previous streaming deal.

BE

Folk who follow Glencore closely seem to be a bit surprised at the figure.

11:55 am
BE

Some suggestion that there might be a damping of expectations ahead of Thursday's trading update.

BE

Anyway, here's Caz on the sector.

BE

(@cheecky: nah. Not touching that. Sounds bull.)

11:56 am
BE

Upcoming results should revisit familiar themes of depressed earnings, asset
impairments, although further cost cuts could lead to another round of positive
earnings surprises. Other themes could grow in importance, including defining
investment cases in a (largely) post-progressive dividend world, and the
implications of cost deflation vs cost cutting on commodity prices and volume
growth. In our view, GLEN (OW) is best positioned to outperform, with
identifiable upcoming catalysts that should create value even at lower
commodity prices. We expect BHP (UW) will cut its progressive dividend
more than is priced into the equity, while RIO (OW) will stand firm.
Widespread negativity on AAL’s (UW) strategy poses a risk to being short, in
the event of any positive commentary from management.

BE

 RIO (OW) key focus dividend: We forecast 25% YE’15 gearing, staying
within the 20-30% target until 2018. Therefore we expect ongoing
commitment to the progressive dividend, despite the 8.5% yield being
funded from debt. JPMe 2016-17E capex is already $2.4bn below guidance,
so results will be crucial to reassuring investors over dividend sustainability.

BE

 BHP (UW) expect at least a 50% dividend cut: We forecast a 50% cut to
BHP’s progressive dividend. Yet even after this we estimate ~$2bnpa cash
burn, ND/EBITDA greater than 3x, and gearing ~35% after $8bn of impairments in
CY’16E. With the progressive policy likely to stay in place, in our view, the
risk of a 75% cut is material and, we believe, not yet priced in to the shares.

11:56 am
BE

 GLEN (OW) catalysts to drive outperformance: We expect GLEN to rerate
as credit risk perceptions improve. S&P’s recent downgrade to BBBcites
EBITDA of $7.0-8.0bn in 2016, but following recent rallies in Cu, Zn
and oil we forecast spot EBITDA of $8.3bn. GLEN is the only diversified to
generate FCF at spot – JPMe ~$5.5bn post working capital in 2016 (27%
FCF yield). An imminent $8.5bn loan refinancing, and stake sale in Ag
(JPMe $2bn for 25%) should also help materially improve credit concerns.

BE

 AAL (UW) strategy needs to evolve to new reality: We are sceptical on
the credibility of AAL’s radical restructuring plan, not least the ability to
execute greater than $2bn of non-core asset disposals and close underperforming assets.
We retain structural concerns around AAL’s long-term investment case, but
25% short interest and the possibility for positive headlines leaves us
cautious of being short into results on 16th Feb.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 241.80, down 13.7 (-5.36%), High: 257.40, Low: 241.10, Volume: 7.11m
12:04 pm
BE

Deutsche-hosted media buyer call. Not positive.

BE

1Q consensus for the UK TV market was +5% to 6%. A number of forecasts had been cut recently on weakening retail spend; supermarkets and DIY particularly cited. ITV was seen up 2-3% underlying, underperforming the market with C4 particularly strong.

BE

Also, ITV player inflates growth. Which we kinda knew, I guess.

12:04 pm
BE

ITV has included its online video service, ITV Player, in its revenue figures cited to media agencies for the first time this year. Player ad revs are c.3% of ITV linear TV ad income. So although ITV was seen up +5% to 6.5% on a headline basis, on a like-for-like basis this is 2-3%. In its financial reporting to the market, the company reports the two items separately; “ITV Family NAR” and in “Online, pay and interactive”. The company has confirmed that it will not be combining the two in its financial reporting, but has done for discussions with media agencies. It stated this would boost figures reported by agencies, but would not confirm whether 3% was the appropriate adjustment.

BE

There are solid grounds to expect ITV to perform better in 2Q. It has Euro2016 rights, easier comps and C4’s strong start to the year was seen as likely to reverse. FY16 was seen up +3-3.5% for ITV ex-Player (+6% to 6.5% headline). But market consensus for ITV Family NAR at +4% is now relying on a far stronger 2Q (comps toughen in 3Q/4Q from the Rugby World Cup). Moreover, revisions since the start of the year have seen some 5-6% ests, which look very demanding. DB ITV Family NAR +2%; 6% below consensus EPS (16.9p). Our ests are unchanged.

BE

Plus the usual structural stuff.

12:05 pm
BE

Linear TV was seen as still robust in the near-term despite falling viewing. The agencies saw it as the safe option for advertisers with a long understanding of relationship between TV campaigns and sales. Spend on online video was seen as accelerating, but only partly drawn from linear TV budgets; mainly from other media. However, the barriers to a more marked shift of linear budgets were seen as largely transitory; poor measurement of online viewing, limited high quality inventory and some inertia amongst media planners. Notably, ITV was seen as losing share in this transition; ITV Player revs FY15 of c£100m meant a share of 17% of the £590m online video market versus 46% in linear TV. Youtube and Facebook were seen at £150m and £90m, respectively.
